xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:title: Windows Security Technical Implementation Guide
xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:description: The Windows Security Technical Implementation Guide (STIG) is published as a tool to improve the security of Department of Defense (DoD) information systems. Comments or proposed revisions to this document should be sent via e-mail to the following address: disa.letterkenny.FSO.mbx.stig-customer-support-mailbox@mail.mil.

xccdf:metadata.dc:contributor: National Institute of Standards and Technology
xccdf:metadata.dc:publisher: National Institute of Standards and Technology
xccdf:metadata.dc:creator: National Institute of Standards and Technology

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Shutdown: Allow System to be Shut Down Without Having to Log On
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Shutdown: Allow System to be Shut Down Without Having to Log On

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Number of Previous Logons to Cache (in Case Domain Controller Is Not Available)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Defines the number of last logon credentials cached for users who log on interactively to a system.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit: Shut down system immediately if unable to log security audits
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Audit: Shut down system immediately if unable to log security audits

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts and shares
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Network access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts and shares This security setting determines whether anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts and shares is allowed. Windows allows anonymous users to perform certain activities, such as enumerating the names of domain accounts and network shares. This is convenient, for example, when an administrator wants to grant access to users in a trusted domain that does not maintain a reciprocal trust. If you do not want to allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts and shares, then enable this policy. Default: Disabled.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Account Lockout Threshold
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The maximum number of failed attempts that can occur before the account is locked out

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Reset Account Lockout Counter After
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The time period in seconds to be used with the lockout threshold value. For example, if the threshold is set to 10 attempts and the duration is set to 15 minutes, then if more than 10 failed login attempts occur with a single user account within a 15-minute period, the account will be disabled. 15 minutes = 900 seconds

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Maximum Password Age
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The maximum age in seconds before a password expires. (90 days = 7776000 seconds; 60 days = 5184000)

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Minimum Password Age
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The minimum age in seconds before a password may be changed. 1 day = 86400 seconds

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Enforce Password History
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The number of passwords remembered

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Status of Guest Account
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This value defines the desired status of the built-in Guest account. 0 = disabled; 1 = enabled.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Microsoft network server: Disconnect clients when logon hours expire
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Users should not be permitted to remain logged on to the network after they have exceeded their permitted logon hours. In many cases, this indicates that a user forgot to log off before leaving for the day. However, it may also indicate that a user is attempting unauthorized access at a time when the system may be less closely monitored.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Microsoft network client: Send unencrypted password to third-party SMB servers
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Some non-Microsoft SMB servers only support unencrypted (plain text) password authentication. Sending plain text passwords across the network, when authenticating to an SMB server, reduces the overall security of the environment. Check with the Vendor of the SMB server to see if there is a way to support encrypted password authentication.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Enforce Password Complexity
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This value determines whether Windows 7 implements a minimum level of strong password filtering. 1 = enabled

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network Security: LAN Manager Authentication Level
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Network Security: LAN Manager Authentication Level

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Interactive logon: Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Disabling the Ctrl+Alt+Del security attention sequence can compromise system security. Because only Windows responds to the Ctrl+Alt+Del security sequence, you can be assured that any passwords you enter following that sequence are sent only to Windows. If you eliminate the sequence requirement, malicious programs can request and receive your Windows password. Disabling this sequence also suppresses a custom logon banner. 0 = disabled

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Recovery Console: Allow Floppy Copy and Access to All Drives and All Folders
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Recovery Console: Allow Floppy Copy and Access to All Drives and All Folders

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Recovery Console: Allow Automatic Administrative Logon
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Recovery Console: Allow Automatic Administrative Logon

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communications (if client agrees)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communications (if client agrees). This check verifies that the server policy is set to sign packets if the client agrees.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Domain member: Digitally encrypt secure channel data (when possible)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Requests sent on the secure channel are authenticated, and sensitive information (such as passwords) is encrypted, but not all information is encrypted. If this policy is enabled, outgoing secure channel traffic should be encrypted.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Domain member: Digitally sign secure channel data (when possible)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Requests sent on the secure channel are authenticated, and sensitive information (such as passwords) is encrypted, but the channel is not integrity checked. If this policy is enabled, all outgoing secure channel traffic should be signed.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Domain member: Disable machine account password changes
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer account passwords are changed automatically every seven days. Enabling this policy to disable automatic password changes can make the system more vulnerable to malicious access. Frequent password changes can be a significant safeguard for your system. If this policy is disabled, a new password for the computer account will be generated every week.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Microsoft network client: Digitally sign communications (if server agrees)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the client policy is set to sign packets if the server agrees.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Devices: Allow only administrators to format and eject removable media
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Verifies that only the correct users are allowed to format and eject removable media 0 - Only Administrator, 1 - Only Administrators and power users, 2 - Only Administrators and Interactive user

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Prompt User to Change Password Before Expiration
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This setting configures the system to display a warning to users telling them how many days are left before their password expires.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: System objects: Strengthen default permissions of internal system objects
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: System objects: Strengthen default permissions of internal system objects

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Amount of Idle Time Required Before Suspending Session
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Administrators should use this setting to control when a computer disconnects an inactive SMB session. If client activity resumes, the session is automatically reestablished.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Enforce Reversible Encryption When Storing Passwords
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This value determines whether Windows 7 is configured to prevent passwords from being stored using a two-way hash. 1 = enabled

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Solicited Remote Assistance
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System: Remote Assistance - Solicited Remote Assistance.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Accounts: Limit local account use to blank passwords to console logon only
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This value defines the desired status of limiting the use of blank passwords. 1 = enabled; 0= disabled

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Maximum Machine Account Password Age
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This setting controls the maximum password age that a machine account may have.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Require Strong Session Key
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This setting controls the required strength of a session key.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Require Domain Controller Authentication to Unlock Workstation
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This setting controls the behavior of the system when you attempt to unlock the workstation. If this setting is enabled, the system will pass the credentials to the domain controller (if in a domain) for authentication before allowing the system to be unlocked.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network access: Do not allow storage of credentials or .NET Passports for network authentication
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Network access: Do not allow storage of credentials or .NET Passports for network authentication

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network access: Let Everyone permissions apply to anonymous users
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Network access: Let Everyone permissions apply to anonymous users

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network access: Sharing and security model for local accounts
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Network access: Sharing and security model for local accounts

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network security: Do not store LAN Manager hash value on next password change
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Network security: Do not store LAN Manager hash value on next password change

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network security: Force logoff when logon hours expire
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Network security: Force logoff when logon hours expire

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network Security: LDAP client signing requirements
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Network Security: LDAP client signing requirements

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: System Cryptography: Use FIPS compliant algorithms for encryption, hashing, and signing
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: System Cryptography: Use FIPS compliant algorithms for encryption, hashing, and signing

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: System objects: Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: System objects: Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Always prompt for password upon connection
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Always prompt for password upon connection

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Set client connection encryption level
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Set client connection encryption level

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Do not use temporary folders per session
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Do not use temporary folders per session

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Do not delete temp folder upon exit
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Do not delete temp folder upon exit

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Offer Remote Assistance
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System: Remote Assistance - Offer Remote Assistance.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn Off Windows Error Reporting
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Internet Communication Management\Internet Communication settings: Turn Off Windows Error Reporting.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: MSS: (SafeDllSearchMode) Enable Safe DLL search mode (recommended)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Most programs on the Windows platform make use of various Dynamic Link Libraries (DLL) to avoid having to reimplement functionality. The operating system actually loads several DLLs for each program, depending on what type of program it is. When the program does not specify an absolute location for a DLL, the default search order is used to locate it. By default, the search order used by the operating system is as follows: 1. Memory 2. KnownDLLs 3. Manifests and .local 4. Application directory 5. Current working directory 6. System directories (%systemroot%, %systemroot%\system, and %systemroot%\system32) 7. The path variable The fact that the current working directory is searched before the system directories can be used by someone with access to the file system to cause a program launched by a user to load a spoofed DLL. If a user launches a program by double-clicking a document, the current working directory is actually the location of the document. If a DLL in that directory has the same name as a system DLL in that location will then be loaded instead of the system DLL. This attack vector was actually used by the Nimda virus. To combat this, a new setting was created in Service Pack 3, which moves the current working directory to after the system directories in the search order. To avoid application compatibility issues, however, this switch was not turned on by default. To turn it on, set the following registry valueMACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\SafeDllSearchMode

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Prevent Automatic Updates
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Disable Media Player for automatic updates policy should be set correctly.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: MSS: (WarningLevel) Percentage threshold for the security event log at which the system will generate a warning
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Windows Server 2003 and Service Pack 3 for Windows 2000 include a new feature for generating a security audit in the security event log when the security log reaches a user defined threshold. Note: new to W2K3 HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Eventlog\Security\WarningLevel

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: MSS: (DisableIPSourceRouting) IP source routing protection level (protects against packet spoofing)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: IP source routing is a mechanism that allows the sender to determine the IP route that a datagram should take through the network. Microsoft recommends to configure this setting to Not Defined for enterprise environments and to Highest Protection for high security environments to completely disable source routing. HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Tcpip\Parameters\DisableIPSourceRouting

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: MSS: (EnableICMPRedirect) Allow ICMP redirects to override OSPF generated routes
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects cause the stack to plumb host routes. These routes override the Open Shortest Path First (OSPF)generated routes, attackers can use source routed packets to conceal the address of their computer. HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Tcpip\Parameters\EnableICMPRedirect

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: MSS: (KeepAliveTime)How often keep-alive packets are sent in milliseconds
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This value controls how often TCP attempts to verify that an idle connection is still intact by sending a keep-alive packet. If the remote computer is still reachable, it acknowledges the keep-alive packet. HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Tcpip\Parameters\KeepAliveTime

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: MSS: (NoNameReleaseOnDemand) Allow computer to ignore NetBIOS name release requests except from WINS servers
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: MSS: (NoNameReleaseOnDemand) Allow computer to ignore NetBIOS name release requests except from WINS servers

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: MSS: (TCPMaxDataRetransmissions) How many times unacknowledged data is retransmitted (3 recommended, 5 is default)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: MSS: (TCPMaxDataRetransmissions) How many times unacknowledged data is retransmitted (3 recommended, 5 is default)

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: MSS: (ScreenSaverGracePeriod) The time in seconds before the screen saver grace period expires (0 recommended)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Setting Added to Registry to Make Screensaver Password Protection Immediate The default grace period allowed for user movement before the screen saver lock takes effect is five seconds. Leaving the grace period in the default setting makes your computer vulnerable to a potential attack from someone walking up to the console to attempt to log onto the system before the lock takes effect. An entry to the registry can be made to adjust the length of the grace period.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Registry Policy Processing
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System: Group Policy - Registry Policy Processing.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Domain member: Digitally encrypt or sign secure channel data (always)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Domain member: Digitally encrypt or sign secure channel data (always). Requests sent on the secure channel are authenticated, and sensitive information (such as passwords) is encrypted or signed. If this policy is enabled, outgoing secure channel traffic should be encrypted.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Client Digitally Sign Communications (Always)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the client policy is set to always sign packets.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communications (always)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This check verifies that the server policy is set to always sign packets.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network access: Restrict anonymous access to Named Pipes and Shares
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Network access: Restrict anonymous access to Named Pipes and Shares

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Minimum Password Length
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The minimum number of characters required for a password

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Interactive logon: Do not display last user name
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This setting determines whether the name of the last user to log on to the computer will be displayed in the Windows logon dialog box.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit: Audit the access of global system objects
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Controls the ability to audit access of global systems objects. When this setting is enabled, system objects such as mutexes, events, semaphores, and DOS devices, are created with a default system access control list (SACL).

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit: Audit the use of Backup and Restore privilege
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Controls the ability to audit the use of all user privileges, including Backup and Restore. If this policy is disabled, certain user rights will not be audited even if Audit privilege use audit policy is enabled.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Audit: Force audit policy subcategory settings (Windows Vista or later) to override audit policy category settings
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Audit: Force audit policy subcategory settings (Windows Vista or later) to override audit policy category settings

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: MSS: (Hidden) Hide computer from the browse list (Not Recommended except for highly secure environments)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Hiding the computer from the Browse List removes one method attackers might use to gether information about computers on the network.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: MSS: (NoDefaultExempt) Configure IPSec exemptions for various types of network traffic
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: MSS: (NoDefaultExempt) Configure IPSec exemptions for various types of network traffic

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This security setting determines the behavior of Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators in Admin Approval Mode
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This security setting determines the behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This security setting determines the behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Detect application installations and prompt for elevation
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This security setting determines the behavior of application installation detection for the computer.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Only elevate UIAccess applications that are installed in secure locations
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This security setting will enforce the requirement that applications requesting to be run with a UIAccess integrity level must reside in a secure location on the file system.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Run all administrators in Admin Approval Mode
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This security setting determines the behavior of all UAC policies for the entire system.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This security setting determines whether the elevation prompt appears on the interactive users desktop or the secure desktop.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Virtualize file and registry write failures to per-user locations
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This security setting enables the redirection of application write failures to defined locations in both the registry and file system. This feature mitigates those applications that historically ran as administrator and wrote runtime application data to protected locations (%ProgramFiles%, %Windir%, %Windir%\system32, or HKLM\Software\...). Virtualization facilitates the running of applications that historically failed to run as standard user because of application write failures.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Enumerate administrator accounts on elevation
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Credential User Interface: Enumerate administrator accounts on elevation.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Do not allow passwords to be saved
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Do not allow passwords to be saved

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Allow users to connect remotely using Remote Desktop Services
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Allow users to connect remotely using Remote Desktop Services

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Do not allow drive redirection
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Do not allow drive redirection

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Restrictions for Unauthenticated RPC clients
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System: Remote Assistance - Restrictions for Unauthenticated RPC clients. (Enabled: Authenticated = 1)

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: RPC Endpoint Mapper Client Authentication
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System: Remote Assistance - RPC Endpoint Mapper Client Authentication.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn off Internet download for Web publishing and online ordering wizards
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Internet Communication Management\Internet Communication settings: Turn off Internet download for Web publishing and online ordering wizards.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn off printing over HTTP
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Internet Communication Management\Internet Communication settings: Turn off printing over HTTP.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn off downloading of print drivers over HTTP
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Internet Communication Management\Internet Communication settings: Turn off downloading of print drivers over HTTP.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn off Windows Update device driver search prompt
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Turn off Windows Update device driver search prompt

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn Off Microsoft Peer-to-Peer Networking Services
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This setting turns off Microsoft Peer-to-Peer Networking Services. (Enabled=1; Disabled=0; Not Configured)

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Prohibit installation and configuration of Network Bridge on your DNS domain network
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Installation and Configuration of Network Bridge on the DNS Domain Network should be properly configured.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn off Automatic Root Certificates Update
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Turn off Automatic Root Certificates Update

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn off event views Events.asp links
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Internet Communication Management\Internet Communication settings: Turn Off Event Views Events.asp Links.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn Off Internet File Association Service
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Internet Communication Management\Internet Communication settings: Turn Off Internet File Association Service.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn Off the Order Prints Picture Task
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Internet Communication Management\Internet Communication settings: Turn Off the Order Prints Picture Task.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Always Use Classic Logon
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System: Logon - Always Use Classic Logon.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn off shell protocol protected mode
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Turn off shell protocol protected mode

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Prohibit non-administrators from applying vendor signed updates
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This setting controls the ability of non-administrators to install updates that have been digitally signed by the application vendor.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Do Not Show First Use Dialog Boxes
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The Do Not Show First Use Dialog Boxes setting for Windows Media Player should be configured correctly.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Prohibit Access of the Windows Connect Now Wizards
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Prohibit Access of the Windows Connect Now Wizards. (Enabled = 1; Disabled = 0)

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Allow remote access to the PnP interface
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Device Installation: Allow remote access to the PnP interface. (Enabled = 1; Disabled = 0)

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Do not create system restore point when new device driver installed
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Device Installation: Do not create system restore point when new device driver installed. (Enabled = 1; Disabled = 0)

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Do not send a Windows Error Report when a generic driver is installed on a device
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Device Installation: Do not send a Windows Error Report when a generic driver is installed on a device. (Enabled = 0; Disabled = 1)

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn off Windows Update device driver searching
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Internet Communication Management\Internet Communication settings: Turn off Windows Update device driver searching.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn Off Handwriting Recognition Error Reporting
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Internet Communication Management\Internet Communication settings: Turn Off Handwriting Recognition Error Reporting.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Require a Password when a Computer Wakes (On Battery)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Power Management: Sleep Settings - Require a Password when a Computer Wakes (On Battery).

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Require a Password when a Computer Wakes (Plugged)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Power Management: Sleep Settings - Require a Password when a Computer Wakes (Plugged).

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn on session logging
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System: Remote Assistance - Turn on session logging.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn Off Downloading of Game Information
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Game Explorer: Turn Off Downloading of Game Information.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Allow indexing of encrypted files
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Allow indexing of encrypted files

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Prevent indexing uncached Exchange folders
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Prevent indexing uncached Exchange folders

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Configure Microsoft SpyNet Reporting
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: When Windows Defender detects software or changes by software not yet classified for risks, you see how other members responded to the alert. In turn, the action you apply help other members choose how to respond. Your actions also help Microsoft choose which software to investigate for potential threats. You can choose to send basic or additional information about detected software. Additional information helps improve how Windows Defender works. It can include, for example, the location of detected items on your computer if harmful software has been removed. Windows Defender will automatically collect and send the information.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Disable Logging
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: If this setting is enabled Windows Error Reporting events will not be logged to the system event log.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Do Not Send Additional Data
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: If this setting is enabled any additional data requests from Microsoft in response to a Windows Error Reporting event will be automatically declined without notice to the user.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn off Heap termination on corruption
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Turn off Heap termination on corruption

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Report when logon server was not available during user logon
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This policy controls whether the logged on user should be notified if the logon server could not be contacted during logon and he has been logged on using previously stored account information.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This security setting will enforce public key infrastructure (PKI) signature checks on any interactive application that requests elevation of privilege. Enterprise administrators can control which administrative applications are allowed through the certificates in the local computers Trusted Publishers certificate store.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Disabled the Windows Messenger Customer Experience Improvement Program
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Internet Communication Management\Internet Communication settings: Turn off the Windows Messenger Customer Experience Improvement Program (Enabled = CEIP off; Disabled - CEIP on).

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Status of Admin Account
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This value defines the desired status of the built-in Account account. 0 = disabled; 1 = enabled.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Maximum System Log Size
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The value defines the maximum size (in KB) of the system log.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Maximum Setup Log Size
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The value defines the maximum size (in KB) of the setup log.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn on Basic feed authentication over HTTP
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Basic authentication for RSS feeds over HTTP must be turned off.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Maximum Security Log Size
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The value defines the maximum size (in KB) of the security log.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Maximum Application Log Size
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: The value defines the maximum size (in KB) of the application log.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Teredo State
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to configure Teredo state.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: ISATAP State
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to configure ISATAP state.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: IP HTTPS State
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to configure IP HTTPS state.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: 6to4_state
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to configure 6to4 state.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Microsoft network server: SPN Target name validation
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This policy setting controls the level of validation a computer with shared folders or printers (the server) performs on the service principal name (SPN) that is provided by the client computer when it establishes a session using the server message block (SMB) protocol.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network security: Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows services running as Local System to use the computer identity when negotiating NTLM authentication.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network security: Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows the system to fall back no a NULL session.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network Security: Allow PKU2U authentication requests to this computer to use online identities
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2 introduce an extension to the Negotiate authentication package, Spnego.dll. In previous versions of Windows, Negotiate decides whether to use Kerberos or NTLM for authentication. The extension SSP for Negotiate, Negoexts, which is treated as an authentication protocol by Windows, supports Microsoft SSPs including PKU2U.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network Security: Configure encryption types allowed for Kerberos
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to specify the allowed encryption types for Kerberos authentication.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: MSS: (DisableIPSourceRouting IPv6) IP source routing protection level (protects against packet spoofing)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Allowing source routed network traffic allows attackers to obscure their identity and location.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: MSS: (TcpMaxDataRetransmissions IPv6) How many times unacknowledged data is retransmitted (3 recommended, 5 is default)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: MSS: (TcpMaxDataRetransmissions IPv6) How many times unacknowledged data is retransmitted (3 recommended, 5 is default).

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: require_domain_users_to_elevate_when_setting_a_networks_location
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Require Domain users to elevate when setting a networks location should be properly configured.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: require_domain_users_to_elevate_when_setting_a_networks_location
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Route all traffic through the internal network should be properly configured.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: prevent_device_metadata_retrieval_from_the_internet
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: prevent_device_metadata_retrieval_from_the_internet

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: specify_search_order_for_device_driver_source_locations
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: specify_search_order_for_device_driver_source_locations

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: turn_off_handwriting_personalization_data_sharing
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: turn_off_handwriting_personalization_data_sharing

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Microsoft support diagnostic tool: turn on msdt interactive communication with support provider
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Microsoft support diagnostic tool: turn on msdt interactive communication with support provider

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: troubleshooting_allow_user_to_access_online_troubleshooting_content_on_microsoft_servers_from_the_troubleshooting_control_panel
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: troubleshooting_allow_user_to_access_online_troubleshooting_content_on_microsoft_servers_from_the_troubleshooting_control_panel

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Enable or disable perftrack
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This policy setting specifies whether to enable or disable tracking of responsiveness events.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Turn off program inventory
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This policy controls the state of the Program Inventory collector in the system.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: turn_off_autoplay_for_non_volume_devices
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This policy setting determines whether autoplay is enabled for non volume devices.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: turn_off_game_updates
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: turn_off_game_updates

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: prevent_the_computer_from_joining_a_homegroup
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: prevent_the_computer_from_joining_a_homegroup

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: turn_off_data_execution_prevention_for_explorer
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: turn_off_data_execution_prevention_for_explorer

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: default_behavior_for_autorun
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: default_behavior_for_autorun

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Network access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Network access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts This security setting determines what additional permissions will be granted for anonymous connections to the computer. Windows allows anonymous users to perform certain activities, such as enumerating the names of domain accounts and network shares. This is convenient, for example, when an administrator wants to grant access to users in a trusted domain that does not maintain a reciprocal trust. This security option allows additional restrictions to be placed on anonymous connections as follows: Enabled: Do not allow enumeration of SAM accounts. This option replaces Everyone with Authenticated Users in the security permissions for resources. Disabled: No additional restrictions. Rely on default permissions. Default on workstations: Enabled. Default on server:Disabled. Important This policy has no impact on domain controllers.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: MSS: (PerformRouterDiscovery) Allow IRDP to detect and configure DefaultGateway addresses (could lead to DoS)
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This setting is used to enable or disabled the Internet Router Discovery Protocol (IRDP). IRDP allows the system to detect and configure Default Gateway addresses automatically. HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Tcpip\Parameters\PerformRouterDiscovery

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Prevent Windows Media DRM Internet Access
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Prevents Windows Media Digital Rights Management (DRM) from accessing the Internet (or intranet). When enabled, Windows Media DRM is prevented from accessing the Internet (or intranet) for license acquisition and security upgrades.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Extend point and print connection to search Windows update and use alternate cionnection if needed
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Extend Point and Print connection to search Windows Update and use alternate cooection if needed

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The shutdown option must be available from the logon dialog box.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Preventing display of the shutdown button in the logon dialog box may encourage a hard shut down with the power button. (However, displaying the shutdown button may allow individuals to shut down a system anonymously.)</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECSC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Shutdown: Allow system to be shutdown without having to log on" to "Enabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The system must not halt when the security event log has reached its maximum size.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>A system that is configured to halt if an event log becomes full can create a denial of service situation on a workstation.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECRR-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Audit: Shut down system immediately if unable to log security audits" to "Disabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The built-in guest account must be disabled.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>A system faces an increased vulnerability threat if the built-in guest account is not disabled. This account is a known account that exists on all Windows systems and cannot be deleted. This account is initialized during the installation of the operating system with no password assigned.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>IAAC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Accounts: Guest account status" to "Disabled".

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Forcibly Disconnect when Logon Hours Expire

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Users must be forcibly disconnected when their logon hours expire.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Users must not be permitted to remain logged on to the network after they have exceeded their permitted logon hours. In many cases, this indicates that a user forgot to log off before leaving for the day. However, it may also indicate that a user is attempting unauthorized access at a time when the system may be less closely monitored. Forcibly disconnecting users when logon hours expire protects critical and sensitive network data from exposure to unauthorized personnel with physical access to the computer.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECSC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Microsoft Network Server: Disconnect Clients When Logon Hours Expire" to "Enabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The Recovery Console SET command must be disabled.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>The Recovery Console SET command allows environment variables to be set in the Recovery Console. This permits access to all drives and folders and the copying of files to removable media which could expose sensitive information.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECCD-1, ECCD-2</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Recovery Console: Allow floppy copy and access to all drives and folders" to "Disabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The Recovery Console option must be set to prevent automatic logon to the system.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>If this option is enabled, the Recovery Console does not require a password and automatically logs on to the system. This could allow unauthorized administrative access to the system.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECCD-1, ECCD-2</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Recovery Console: Allow automatic administrative logon" to "Disabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Outgoing secure channel traffic must be encrypted when possible.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Requests sent on the secure channel are authenticated, and sensitive information (such as passwords) is encrypted, but not all information is encrypted. If this policy is enabled, outgoing secure channel traffic will be encrypted.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives>If the value for Domain Member: Digitally encrypt or sign secure channel data (always) is set to Enabled, this would not be a finding.</FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECCT-1, ECCT-2</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Domain Member: Digitally encrypt secure channel data (when possible)" to "Enabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The computer account password must not be prevented from being reset.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Computer account passwords are changed automatically on a regular basis. Disabling automatic password changes can make the system more vulnerable to malicious access. Frequent password changes can be a significant safeguard for your system. A new password for the computer account will be generated every 30 days.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>IAIA-1, IAIA-2</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Domain Member: Disable Machine Account Password Changes" to "Disabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The default permissions of global system objects must be increased.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Windows systems maintain a global list of shared system resources such as DOS device names, mutexes, and semaphores. Each type of object is created with a default DACL that specifies who can access the objects with what permissions. If this policy is enabled, the default DACL is stronger, allowing non-admin users to read shared objects, but not modify shared objects that they did not create.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECSC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "System Objects: Strengthen default permissions of internal system objects (e.g. Symbolic links)" to "Enabled".

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Idle Time Before Suspending a Session.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The amount of idle time required before suspending a session must be properly set.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Open sessions can increase the avenues of attack on a system. This setting is used to control when a computer disconnects an inactive SMB session. If client activity resumes, the session is automatically re-established. This protects critical and sensitive network data from exposure to unauthorized personnel with physical access to the computer.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECSC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Microsoft Network Server: Amount of idle time required before suspending a session" to "15" minutes or less.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Reversible password encryption must be disabled.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Storing passwords using reversible encryption is essentially the same as storing clear-text versions of the passwords. For this reason, this policy must never be enabled.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>IAIA-1, IAIA-2</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Account Policies -> Password Policy -> "Store password using reversible encryption" to "Disabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Unauthorized remotely accessible registry paths must not be configured.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>The registry is integral to the function, security, and stability of the Windows system. Some processes may require remote access to the registry. This setting controls which registry paths are accessible from a remote computer. These registry paths must be limited, as they could give unauthorized individuals access to the registry.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECCD-1, ECCD-2</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Network access: Remotely accessible registry paths" with the following entries: System\CurrentControlSet\Control\ProductOptions System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Server Applications Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Local accounts with blank passwords must be restricted to prevent access from the network.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>An account without a password can allow unauthorized access to a system as only the username would be required. Password policies should prevent accounts with blank passwords from existing on a system. However, if a local account with a blank password did exist, enabling this setting will prevent network access, limiting the account to local console logon only.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>IAIA-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Accounts: Limit local account use of blank passwords to console logon only" to "Enabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The maximum age for machine account passwords must be set to requirements.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Computer account passwords are changed automatically on a regular basis. This setting controls the maximum password age that a machine account may have. This setting must be set to no more than 30 days, ensuring the machine changes its password monthly.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>IAIA-1, IAIA-2</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Domain Member: Maximum Machine Account Password Age" to "30" or less (excluding 0 which is unacceptable).

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The system must be configured to require a strong session key.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>A computer connecting to a domain controller will establish a secure channel. Requiring strong session keys enforces 128-bit encryption between systems. </VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECSC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Domain Member: Require Strong (Windows 2000 or Later) Session Key" to "Enabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Domain Controller authentication must not be required to unlock the workstation.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>This setting controls the behavior of the system when there is an attempt to unlock the workstation. If this setting is enabled, the system will pass the credentials to the domain controller (if in a domain) for authentication before allowing the system to be unlocked. This may cause a denial of service if the workstation loses connectivity to the domain controller.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECSC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Interactive logon: Require domain controller authentication to unlock workstation" to "Disabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The system must be configured to prevent anonymous users from having the same rights as the Everyone group.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Access by anonymous users must be restricted. If this setting is enabled, then anonymous users have the same rights and permissions as the built-in Everyone group. Anonymous users must not have these permissions or rights.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECCD-1, ECCD-2, ECLP-1, ECSC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Network access: Let everyone permissions apply to anonymous users" to "Disabled".

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Sharing and Security Model for Local Accounts

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The system must be configured to use the Classic security model.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Windows includes two network-sharing security models - Classic and Guest only. With the Classic model, local accounts must be password protected; otherwise, anyone can use guest user accounts to access shared system resources.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECLO-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Network access: Sharing and security model for local accounts" to "Classic - local users authenticate as themselves".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The system must be configured to prevent the storage of the LAN Manager hash of passwords.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>The LAN Manager hash uses a weak encryption algorithm and there are several tools available that use this hash to retrieve account passwords. This setting controls whether or not a LAN Manager hash of the password is stored in the SAM the next time the password is changed. </VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECSC-1, IAIA-1, IAIA-2</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Network security: Do not store LAN Manager hash value on next password change" to "Enabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The system must be configured to the required LDAP client signing level.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>This setting controls the signing requirements for LDAP clients. This setting must be set to Negotiate signing or Require signing, depending on the environment and type of LDAP server in use.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECSC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Network security: LDAP client signing requirements" to "Negotiate signing" at a minimum.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The system must be configured to require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>This setting controls the behavior of non-Windows subsystems when dealing with the case of arguments or commands. Case sensitivity could lead to the access of files or commands that must be restricted. To prevent this from happening, case insensitivity restrictions must be required.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECSC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "System Object: Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems" to "Enabled".

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Anonymous Access to Named Pipes and Shares

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Anonymous access to Named Pipes and Shares must be restricted.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Allowing anonymous access to named pipes or shares provides the potential for unauthorized system access. This setting restricts access to those defined in "Network access: Named Pipes that can be accessed anonymously" and "Network access: Shares that can be accessed anonymously", both of which must be blank under other requirements.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECSC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Network access: Restrict anonymous access to Named Pipes and Shares" to "Enabled".

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Audit Access of Global System Objects

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing Access of Global System Objects must be turned off.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Maintaining an audit trail of system activity logs can help identify configuration errors, troubleshoot service disruptions, and analyze compromises that have occurred, as well as detect attacks. Audit logs are necessary to provide a trail of evidence in case the system or network is compromised. Collecting this data is essential for analyzing the security of information assets and detecting signs of suspicious and unexpected behavior. This setting prevents the system from setting up a default system access control list for certain system objects, which could create a very large number of security events, filling the security log in Windows and making it difficult to identify actual issues.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECSC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Audit: Audit the access of global system objects" to "Disabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Auditing of Backup and Restore Privileges must be turned off.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Maintaining an audit trail of system activity logs can help identify configuration errors, troubleshoot service disruptions, and analyze compromises that have occurred, as well as detect attacks. Audit logs are necessary to provide a trail of evidence in case the system or network is compromised. Collecting this data is essential for analyzing the security of information assets and detecting signs of suspicious and unexpected behavior. This setting prevents the system from generating audit events for every file backed up or restored which could fill the security log in Windows, making it difficult to identify actual issues.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECSC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Audit: Audit the use of Backup and Restore privilege" to "Disabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: User Account Control must be configured to detect application installations and prompt for elevation.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>User Account Control (UAC) is a security mechanism for limiting the elevation of privileges, including administrative accounts, unless authorized. This setting requires Windows to respond to application installation requests by prompting for credentials.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECCD-1, ECCD-2</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "User Account Control: Detect application installations and prompt for elevation" to "Enabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: User Account Control must only elevate UIAccess applications that are installed in secure locations.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>User Account Control (UAC) is a security mechanism for limiting the elevation of privileges, including administrative accounts, unless authorized. This setting configures Windows to only allow applications installed in a secure location on the file system, such as the Program Files or the Windows\System32 folders, to run with elevated privileges.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECCD-1, ECCD-2</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "User Account Control: Only elevate UIAccess applications that are installed in secure locations" to "Enabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: User Account Control must run all administrators in Admin Approval Mode, enabling UAC.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>User Account Control (UAC) is a security mechanism for limiting the elevation of privileges, including administrative accounts, unless authorized. This setting enables UAC.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECCD-1, ECCD-2</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "User Account Control: Run all administrators in Admin Approval Mode" to "Enabled".

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: UAC - Non UAC Compliant Application Virtualization

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: User Account Control must virtualize file and registry write failures to per-user locations.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>User Account Control (UAC) is a security mechanism for limiting the elevation of privileges, including administrative accounts, unless authorized. This setting configures non-UAC compliant applications to run in virtualized file and registry entries in per-user locations, allowing them to run.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECCD-1, ECCD-2</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "User Account Control: Virtualize file and registry write failures to per-user locations" to "Enabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Windows Defender SpyNet membership must be disabled.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Some features may communicate with the vendor, sending system information or downloading data or components for the feature. Turning off this capability will prevent potentially sensitive information from being sent outside the enterprise and uncontrolled updates to the system. This setting disables SpyNet membership and reporting.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECSC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Administrative Templates -> Windows Components -> Windows Defender -> "Configure Microsoft Active Protection Service Reporting " to "Disabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Windows must elevate all applications in User Account Control, not just signed ones.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>User Account Control (UAC) is a security mechanism for limiting the elevation of privileges, including administrative accounts, unless authorized. This setting configures whether Windows elevates all applications, not just signed ones.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECCD-1, ECCD-2</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated" to "Disabled".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts must not be allowed.
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: <VulnDiscussion>Anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts allows anonymous log on users (null session connections) to list all accounts names, thus providing a list of potential points to attack the system.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls>ECSC-1</IAControls>
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:fixtext: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Security Settings -> Local Policies -> Security Options -> "Network access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts" to "Enabled".

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Security Patches
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: Securing a given computer has become increasingly important. As such, it is essential to keep a host up to current patch levels to eliminate known vulnerabilities and weaknesses. In conjunction with antivirus software and a personal firewall, patching goes a long way to securing a host against outside attacks and exploitation. Microsoft provides two mechanisms for distributing security updates: Automatic Updates and Microsoft Update. In smaller environments, either method may be sufficient for keeping systems current with patches. Other environments typically have a software change management control process or a patch management program that tests patches before deploying them; distribution may then occur through local Windows Update Services (WUS) or Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) servers, which provide approved security patches for use by the Automatic Updates feature.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Security Patches Up-To-Date
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: All known security patches have been installed.

oval_definitions.xsi:schemaLocation: http://oval.mitre.org/XMLSchema/oval-definitions-5#windows windows-definitions-schema.xsd http://oval.mitre.org/XMLSchema/oval-definitions-5#windows windows-definitions-schema.xsd http://oval.mitre.org/XMLSchema/oval-definitions-5#independent independent-definitions-schema.xsd http://oval.mitre.org/XMLSchema/oval-definitions-5 oval-definitions-schema.xsd http://oval.mitre.org/XMLSchema/oval-common-5 oval-common-schema.xsd http://oval.mitre.org/XMLSchema/oval-definitions-5#linux linux-definitions-schema.xsd http://oval.mitre.org/XMLSchema/oval-definitions-5#unix unix-definitions-schema.xsd

metadata.title: Lockout Duration
metadata.description: Lockout duration must meet minimum requirements.

criterion.comment: Verifies 'Account lockout duration' is set to '0'

metadata.title: Bad Logon Attempts
metadata.description: The number of allowed bad logon attempts must meet minimum requirements.

criterion.comment: Verifies 'Account lockout threshold' is set to '3' or less
Verifies 'Account lockout threshold' is not set to '0'

metadata.title: Bad Logon Counter Reset
metadata.description: The time before the bad-logon counter is reset must meet minimum requirements.

criterion.comment: Verifies 'Reset account lockout counter after' is set to at least '60' minutes

metadata.title: Reversible Password Encryption
metadata.description: Reversible password encryption must be disabled.

criterion.comment: Verifies 'Store password using reversible encryption' is set to 'Disabled'

metadata.title: IPSec Exemptions
metadata.description: IPSec Exemptions must be limited.

criterion.comment: Verifies 'MSS: (NoDefaultExempt) Configure IPSec exemptions for various types of network traffic' is set to'Multicast, broadcast and ISAKMP exempt (best for Windows XP)'

metadata.title: TS/RDS - Time Limit for Disc. Session
metadata.description: Remote Desktop Services must be configured to set a time limit for disconnected sessions.

criterion.comment: Verifies 'Set time limit for disconnected sessions' is set to 'Enabled' and 'End a disconnected session' is set to '1 minute'

metadata.title: TS/RDS - Time Limit for Idle Session
metadata.description: Remote Desktop Services must be configured to disconnect an idle session after the specified time period.

criterion.comment: Verifies 'Set time limit for active but idle Remote Desktop Services sessions' is set to 'Enabled'; 'Idle session limit' is set to 15 minutes or less
Verifies 'Idle session limit' is not set to '0'

metadata.title: TS/RDS - Remote User Connections
metadata.description: Users must be prevented from connecting using Remote Desktop Services.

criterion.comment: Verifies 'Allow users to connect remotely using Remote Desktop Services' is set to 'Disabled'

metadata.title: TS/RDS - Drive Redirection
metadata.description: Local drives must be prevented from sharing with Remote Desktop Session Hosts.

criterion.comment: Verifies 'Do not allow drive redirection' is set to 'Enabled'

metadata.title: Name-Release Attacks
metadata.description: The system must be configured to ignore NetBIOS name release requests except from WINS servers.

criterion.comment: Verifies 'MSS: (NoNameReleaseOnDemand) Allow computer to ignore NetBIOS name release requests except from WINS servers' is set to 'Enabled'

metadata.title: Root Certificates Update
metadata.description: Root Certificates must not be updated automatically from the Microsoft site.

criterion.comment: Verifies 'Turn off Automatic Root Certificates Update' is set to 'Enabled'

metadata.title: Halt on Audit Failure
metadata.description: The system must not halt when the security event log has reached its maximum size.

criterion.comment: Verifies 'Audit: Shut down system immediately if unable to log security audits' is set to 'Disabled'

metadata.title: Network – Mapper I/O Driver
metadata.description: The Mapper I/O network protocol (LLTDIO) driver must be disabled.

criterion.comment: Verifies AllowLLTDIOOnDomain value equals 0
Verifies AllowLLTDIOOnPublicNet value equals 0
Verifies EnableLLTDIO value equals 0
Verifies ProhibitLLTDIOOnPrivateNet value equals 0

metadata.title: Network – Responder Driver
metadata.description: The Responder network protocol driver must be disabled.

criterion.comment: Verifies AllowRspndrOnDomain value equals 0
Verifies AllowRspndrOnPublicNet value equals 0
Verifies EnableRspndr value equals 0
Verifies ProhibitRspndrOnPrivateNet value equals 0

metadata.title: Network - WCN Wireless Configuration
metadata.description: The configuration of wireless devices using Windows Connect Now must be disabled.

criterion.comment: Verifies DisableInBand802DOT11Registrar value equals 0
Verifies DisableFlashConfigRegistrar value equals 0
Verifies DisableUPnPRegistrar value equals 0
Verifies DisableWPDRegistrar value equals 0
Verifies EnableRegistrars value equals 0

metadata.title: Windows Customer Experience Improvement Program
metadata.description: The Windows Customer Experience Improvement Program must be disabled.

criterion.comment: Verifies 'Turn off Windows Customer Experience Improvement Program' is set to 'Disabled'

metadata.title: Driver Install - Device Driver Search Prompt
metadata.description: Users must not be prompted to search Windows Update for device drivers.
